titlestmt.titleproper: Haverhill, Mass. First Congregational Church records, 1719-2012.
titlestmt.author: Zachary Bodnar

seriesstmt.p: Portions of this collection are part of New England's Hidden Histories. Digital historical representations of these portions of the collection can be viewed online.

conventiondeclaration.citation: Describing Archives: A Content Standard, Second Edition

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 28, 2020 at 14:30

did.unittitle: Haverhill, Mass. First Congregational Church records, 1719-2011.
did.abstract: Haverhill was first settled by Puritans in 1640. Rev. John Ward was officially installed as the pastor of the First Parish in 1645 and the first meeting house was constructed in 1648. The second meeting house was completed in 1699 and the third was completed in 1766. In 1833 the First Parish became Unitarian and the Congregationalist dissenters formed the Independent Congregational Church and Society which was later renamed to the Centre Congregational Church and Society. In 1859 a large group of parishioners left the Centre Congregational Church to form the North Congregational Church. In 1940 the Centre and North Churches merged to form the First Congregational Church. In 1963 the North Parish Community Church merged into the First Congregational Church which simultaneously joined the United Church of Christ. In 2010 the First Congregational Church in Haverhill dissolved. This collection contains the administrative, financial, and important membership records of the First Parish Church, North Congregational Church, Centre Congregational Church, First Congregational Church, and North Parish Community Church.

corpname.part: Independent Congregational Church and Society (Haverhill, Mass.)

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted and open to the public.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Items in this collection are subject to U.S. Copyright Law. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine the copyright status of collection items and to secure any permissions necessary for their reproduction and publication. Requests for permission to publish material must be discussed with the archivist or librarian.

Digital Reproductions are protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use the Digital Reproductions in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. In addition, no permission is required from the Congregational Library & Archives for educational uses. For other uses, you need to obtain permission from the Congregational Library & Archives. For additional information regarding copyright, please consult the Congregational Library & Archives' Digital Collections Copyright & Use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the Haverhill, Mass. First Congregational Church records, 1719-2011, RG5027. The Congregational Library & Archives, Boston, MA.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were donated to the Congregational Library & Archives by the First Congregational Church of Haverhill, Massachusetts, in May 2012; Accession 2012-02. Additional materials were transferred from the Haverhill Public Library in 2012; no accession number.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional accruals are expected for this collection in the form of full-text transcription. There is no anticipated date for this accrual.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Originally processed by Christina Prochilo in 2012 using DACS. Additional processing by Sari Mauro in 2013. Collection completely reprocessed in January 2020 by Zachary Bodnar using DACS Second Edition.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The land eventually called Haverhill was first settled by Puritans in 1640. In 1641 Rev. John Ward, from Haverhill England, came to the young settlement and became the first minister; the town was incorporated in1641 and named Haverhill after Ward's birthplace. The town lands were formally purchased from the Pentuckets in 1642. Rev. Ward was officially installed as the pastor of the First Parish in 1645 and the first meeting house was constructed in 1648. Rev. Ward served as the minister until his death in 1693. He was followed by Rev. Benjamin Rolfe and was installed in 1694. Construction on the second meeting house began in 1697 and was completed in 1699.

The town of Haverhill was separated into multiple parishes during the early eighteenth-century. In 1728 the town was divided into two parishes with the formation of the North Parish. The North Parish was transferred to Plaistow, New Hampshire in 1741 and the Rockingham Congregational Church was formed. In 1734 the town was divided yet again with the formation of the West Parish and the East Parish was formed in 1743. In 1748 a bell, imported from London, was installed in the First Parish church. The third meeting house was constructed 1766.

Rev. Dudley Phelps, a strict orthodox Congregationalist, was installed as the pastor of the First Parish in 1828. His strict orthodoxy became a point of contention and the parish dissolved its relation with Rev. Phelps in 1832. The First Parish, which kept the third meeting house, became a Unitarian church after the split. In 1833 the Independent Congregational Church and Society was formed with Rev. Joseph Whittelsey as its first minister. In 1840 the name was changed to Centre Congregational Church and Society. The new church originally worshipped at the Summer Street Church and Academy Hall until 1834 when a new church building was constructed. The church had a small separation in 1839 when seventeen members withdrew to form the Union Evangelical Church of Haverhill. That church was later renamed to the Winter Street Church. The winter street church was dissolved in 1860. By 1859 the Centre Congregational Church had grown significantly and it was decided that a portion of the parish would leave to form a new church in the north of Haverhill. In 1859 100 former members of the Centre Church formed the North Congregational Church. In 1891 some members of both the North and Centre Congregational Churches joined together to form the Union Congregational Church. The Union Congregational Church dissolved in 1932.

The first building of the North Congregational Church was completed in 1860. In the early twentieth-century, the building was renovated with Tiffany memorial windows. In 1929 the North Parish Community Church was formed after the dissolution of the Rockingham Congregational Church in Plaistow, New Hampshire. In 1940 the Centre Congregational Church and North Congregational Church merged to form the First Congregational Church in Haverhill which occupied the North Church building. In 1963 the North Parish Community Church merged into the First Congregational Church; at the same time the First Congregational Church joined the United Church of Christ. In 2010 the 1860 church building was sold and the First Congregational Church was formally dissolved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the administrative, financial, and important membership records of the First Parish Church, North Congregational Church, Centre Congregational Church, First Congregational Church, and North Parish Community Church, all in Haverhill, Massachusetts. Included within this record collection are church meeting minutes, baptismal records, marriage records, death records, financial records, building records, photographs, correspondence, ledgers and record books, sermons, and valuable eighteenth-century membership records such as relations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged into five series. Each series contains the records of a single church. The North Congregational Church and First Congregational Church series have been further divided into several topical sub-series. Except where noted, series, sub-series, folders, and volumes have been arranged into chronological order. Generally, the contents of folders have largely remained in their original order.
Sub-series 2: North Church Sunday School records, 1859-1923
Sub-series 2: Church committees, societies, and groups, 1922-2010
Series 5: North Parish Community Church records, 1924-1970

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: To access digital user's copies via online-interface, a java-enabled web browser is required. Internet Explorer 8.x and later, Firefox 5.x and later, Opera 12 and later, Safari 5.x and later, or any version of Google Chrome are recommended.
Videocassette materials require a videocassette player in order to play their content.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Artifacts and other materials from the First Congregational Church in Haverhill, Massachusetts, were donated to the Peabody Essex Museum in 2012.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Manual of the Centre Congregational Church in Haverhill, Mass. Haverhill: Chase Brothers, 1894.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records created by the First Parish Church in Haverhill, Massachusetts. The majority of the records are relations, though disciplinary records and financial records are also included within the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The relations and disciplinary records have been artificially arranged into alphabetical order in order to facilitate the searching and retrieval of papers of specific individuals.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: These personal records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. An index of the digital reproductions is available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains the personal records and relations of various early members of the First Parish Church. This folder contains the records of people whose last name began with the letters A through B.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains records of disciplinary cases in Haverhill. Punishment in many cases usually consisted of censure — a temporary restriction from attending services and participating in church business — until the guilty party made a formal confession or request for forgiveness.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: The Deacon White financial records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.
The Rev. Edward Barnard financial pamphlet was digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.
The Rev. Edward Barnard financial booklet was digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains the financial records of the First Parish and one of its early ministers. A two page document attributed to Deacon White contains information on parish expenses, tax rates, and meeting minutes. A string bound pamphlet lists the accounts of Rev. Edward Barnard. Many of the entries in the ledger are paired with an entry on the following page: accounts paid with cash or in-kind. A booklet kept by Rev. Edward Barnard contains a list of presents, mostly foodstuffs, received as part of his salary, official or otherwise.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The Edward Barnard items were removed from the John Barnard papers (MS0790) in 2013 and placed into this collection in anticipation of digitization for the New England's Hidden Histories project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records created by the North Congregational Church in Haverhill, Massachusetts. The materials within this series contain church meeting minutes, membership records, annual reports, Sunday school records, financial records, the records of church committees and social groups, as well as the personal papers of select ministers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the administrative records of the North Congregational Church and parish society as well as membership records. Within this sub-series are church meeting minutes, letters of dismission and admission, vital records, disciplinary records, and reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This disbound volume is somewhat confusing and difficult to classify; it appears to include records and materials related to both the North Congregational Church and the First Congregational Church. As the volume appears to begin with the North Congregational Church it has been placed here within the arrangement.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The item from 1875 was removed from the Church records and orders of worship, 1934-1950 folder.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: This material was removed from the Annual reports, 1894, 1902-1910 folder for preservation and descriptive reasons.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: These materials were removed from the Church records, 1917-1947 folder for preservation and descriptive reasons.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: These materials were removed from the Church records, 1859-1899 folder for preservation reasons.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: These records were originally filed with the North Parish Community Church records.

did.unittitle: Church records and orders of worship

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the administrative, financial, and operational records of the North Church Sunday School. Of particular note are the in-depth attendance records and reports.

did.unittitle: Sunday School attendance and recapitulation records
Sunday School weekly attendance and minutes
Sunday School classes and student lists

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the financial records of the North Congregational Church as well as records related to the maintenance and operation of the church building. Included in the sub-series are pew deeds and pew plans, account books, pledge books, and treasurer reports.

did.unittitle: Trust fund records and will extracts

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: This record was originally filed with the North Parish Community Church records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the records of social groups and committees at the North Congregational Church.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the personal papers and reports of a select few ministers from the North Congregational Church.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the Centre Congregational Church in Haverhill, Massachusetts. This series includes administrative records, financial records, membership records, and the records of the Ladies Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the First Congregational Church in Haverhill, Massachusetts. This series contains administrative records, the records of social groups and committees, newsletters and orders of service, financial records, building records, architectural drawings, video records, photographs, and sermon manuscripts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains all visual and audiovisual materials related to the First Congregational Church. The majority of these materials are related to everyday church life and special events.

did.unittitle: Photographs of Dr. H.J. Whitney and Lourie Ann Whitney in Fuzhou, China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder of slides also contains an index of the slides which identify what is captured in many of them.

did.unittitle: Men's Club and building campaign slides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some photographs within this folder have descriptions written on the back of the photograph in pen or pencil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the records of the various social groups, philanthropic organizations, and lay committees of the First Congregational Church. Of particular note are the thorough records kept by the Women's Guild and the Diaconate. This sub-series also contains records related to youth groups, outreach efforts, and planning for the church's future.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder appears to contain records which were forwarded to the Women's Guild and includes a letter of complaint, some financial records, a letter of introduction, and records relating to a posthumous donation.

did.unittitle: Women's Guild sponsorships through World Vision
Board of deacons and deaconesses records
Olive Maynard Society history and clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains records related to an effort by Rev. Ephron Hernandez to gather a Hispanic Congregation and use the First Church facilities as a base for his ministry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a major self-appraisal study and a "Parish Profile Inventory" created by the Center for Social and Religious Research at the Hartford Seminary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the administrative records of the First Congregational Church and records related to the membership of the church. Included in this sub-series are annual reports, letters of admission and dismission, correspondence, council records, vital records, policy documents, anniversary records, registers, and survey results.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: It is very likely that these cards were created at the time of the merger between the North and First churches. Another possibility is that cards from both churches were combined.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: This pamphlet was originally filed with the North Parish Community Church records.

did.unittitle: List of marriages performed by Rev. Frank Graichen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder appears to have been used for unsorted membership records of all types. This folder contains examples of baptismal records, membership transfers, reception letters, marriage records, and obituary records.

did.unittitle: Donation of artifacts to the Peabody Essex Museum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains extensive copies of near weekly newsletters and orders of worship produced by the First Congregational Church. These newsletters are not complete as occasional single issues and some major gaps exist. However, overall, it is a fascinatingly thorough accounting of the weekly activities of the church and church community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains both financial records and records related to the operation and maintenance of the physical church building. Included within this sub series are treasurer and financial committee reports, architectural drawings, audits, records of bequests, and reports on the church's Tiffany windows.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains manuscript sermons preached by ministers at the First Congregational Church.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the North Parish Community Church in Haverhill, Massachusetts, and contains administrative records, financial records, membership records, and records related to the merger between the North Parish and the First Congregational Church.
